questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of generalised weakness, fatigue, shortness of breath, dark cola-colored urine in the morning, recurrent abdominal pain, and bilateral lower limb pain that worsens with walking. Her haemoglobin (Hb) level is 8.2 g/dL, lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) is greater than 2000 U/L, the direct Coombs test is negative, and urinalysis reveals hemoglobinuria. Which of the following is not associated with her condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Clinical history of generalised weakness, Dark cola colored urine in the morning and findings of anaemia, haemoglobinuria and negative Coombs' test suggest Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH). Leukaemia is not a feature of PNH.
  • PNH is an acquired hematopoietic stem cell disorder characterised by:
    • Complement-mediated hemolysis (intravascular)(Option D ruled out)
    • Thrombosis(Option B ruled out)
    • Bone marrow failure(Option C ruled out)
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Somatic mutation in the PIG-A gene → impaired synthesis of glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchored proteins CD55 and CD59.
    • Absence of these proteins leads to uncontrolled complement activation(C3/C5), leading to increased susceptibility to complement-mediated lysis.

questions.text: Single amino acid replacement of valine with glutamine on the haemoglobin β chain is seen in sickle cell disease. What is true about this statement
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Mechanical fragility is increased in SCD.
  • Sickle cell anaemia is caused by a missense single amino acid substitution in the β-globin chai,n by having a Valine residue instead of a Glutamate residue at the 6th amino acid position in β-globin, which results in a tendency for deoxygenated HbS to self-associate into polymers.
  • Normal haemoglobins are tetramers composed of two pairs of similar chains. On average, the normal adult red cell contains 96% HbA (α2β2), 3% HbA2 (α2δ2), and 1% fetal Hb (HbF, α2γ2).
  • In patients with sickle cell anaemia, HbA is completely replaced by HbS, whereas in heterozygous carriers, only about half is replaced. These polymers distort the red cell, which assumes an elongated crescentic, or sickle, shape ,hence becoming mechanically fragile, resulting in Chronic hemolysis and Microvascular occlusive phenomena

Incorrect options:

Osmotic fragility(Option A) is not characteristic of Sickle Cell disease. Osmotic fragility is observed in Hereditary Spherocytosis.

Schistocytes(Option C) are not characteristic diagnostic criteria for Sickle Cell disease. It is observed in Microangiopathic Hemolytic Anaemia (MAHA).

SCD is a Missense Point mutation (Option D). Examples of Nonsense mutations include Duchenne muscular dystrophy, cystic fibrosis, and spinal muscular atrophy

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl came in emergency with jaundice. Blood tests reveal uraemia and thrombocytopenia. A peripheral blood film demonstrates the presence of schistocytes. What is your probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Given the clinical presentation of jaundice, uraemia, thrombocytopenia, and schistocytes on the peripheral blood film, along with the absence of other common features associated with the above conditions, the most probable diagnosis in this case is Microangiopathic Hemolytic Anaemia (MAHA).
  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia is a form of mechanical hemolytic anaemia resulting from intravascular fragmentation and lysis of red cells due to microvascular endothelial abnormalities (like fibrin, platelet thrombi).
  • Common causes include Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), eclampsia, hemolysis, elevated enzymes, low platelet count (HELLP) syndrome, disseminated malignancies and generalised vasculitis.
  • Blood film shows numerous fragmented red cells (schistocytes) and nucleated red cells.

Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia - peripheral blood smear: This specimen from a patient with hemolytic uremic syndrome contains several fragmented red cells.

Incorrect options:

  • Hereditary Spherocytosis (HS):(Option A)
    • HS is a genetic disorder characterised by defects in red blood cell membrane proteins.
    • Clinical features typically include haemolytic anaemia, jaundice, and splenomegaly.
    • While HS can lead to hemolysis and jaundice, it doesn't usually cause thrombocytopenia or the presence of schistocytes. Thrombocytopenia and schistocytes are not typical features of HS.
  • Sickle Cell Anemia:(Option B)
    • Sickle cell anaemia is a genetic disorder causing abnormal haemoglobin production, leading to misshapen red blood cells.
    • It primarily manifests as hemolytic anaemia, jaundice, and vaso-occlusive crises.
    • Thrombocytopenia and schistocytes are not characteristic features of sickle cell anaemia.
  • Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase (G6PD) Deficiency:(Option C)
    • G6PD deficiency is an X-linked genetic disorder affecting red blood cell function.
    • Individuals with G6PD deficiency can experience hemolysis triggered by certain medications or oxidative stressors.
    • While it can cause hemolysis and jaundice in response to specific triggers, it doesn't typically result in thrombocytopenia or the presence of schistocytes.

questions.text: A 1-day-old baby has developed severe jaundice on the neonatal ward. The mother is Rhesus negative and had one previous pregnancy, but she was not administered prophylactic anti-D in the first pregnancy. What is the most probable diagnosis in the given case history?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hemolytic disease of the newborn results from the passage of IgG antibodies from maternal circulation across the placenta into the circulation of the foetal red cells. Besides pregnancy, sensitisation of the mother may result from previous abortions and previous blood transfusions.
  • It occurs due to incompatibilities of ABO or RH blood groups. Rh incompatibilities result in severe hemolytic disease of newborns. It results in intrauterine death from hydrops fetalis. Moderate disease leads to babies born with severe anaemia and jaundice due to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
  • When the level of unconjugated bilirubin exceeds 20 mg/dl, it results in deposition of bile pigments in the basal ganglia of the CNS, called kernicterus and gives permanent brain damage.
  • Hereditary spherocytosis, Sickle cell anaemia and thalassemia do not present immediately after birth(Options A, B, C ruled out).

questions.text: A 6-year-old male presented with severe anaemia and multiple joint pains. Identify the pathognomic abnormal red blood cells in the given peripheral smear of this patient.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This blood peripheral smear is a classic picture of Sickle cell disease, showing sickle-shaped RBCs, target cells, and anisocytosis and poikilocytosis.
  • Clinical Features: Characterised by severe anaemia, recurrent painful and aplastic crises, non-healing leg ulcers, recurrent splenic infarcts with progressive fibrosis, which result in auto-splenectomy.

The pathophysiology of sickle cell anaemia is as follows:


Incorrect options:

Schistocytes (Option A):

  • Schistocytes are irregularly shaped, fragmented RBCs seen in blood smears, indicating mechanical damage to erythrocytes.
  • Seen in conditions like Microangiopathic Hemolytic Anaemia (MAHA), Macroangiopathic Hemolysis(Mechanical Heart Valves, Vascular Devices), Severe Burns, and vasculitis.

Target cells (Options B):

  • Target cells (or codocytes) are red blood cells (RBCs) with a bullseye appearance on peripheral blood smear due to excess membrane relative to haemoglobin content.
  • Seen in conditions like Thalassemias, HbC disease, Sickle cell disease, and Post-splenectomy.

Pencil cells (Option C): Pencil cells are abnormally elongated, thin RBCs with pointed ends, resembling a pencil. They are a type of poikilocyte and are most commonly associated with iron deficiency anaemia.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to the haematology clinic with fatigue, pallor, and mild jaundice since adolescence. She reports a family history of similar symptoms in her brother. On examination, she has pallor and splenomegaly. Her CBC reveals Haemoglobin: 9.2 g/dL, MCV: 65 fL and MCH: 22 pg. Peripheral blood smear shows microcytic, hypochromic RBCs with target cells and basophilic stippling. Which of the following investigations is used to confirm the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of Thalassemia, for which a definitive confirmatory test is Hb electrophoresis.
  • Hb electrophoresis shows a reduced level of HbA (α2β2) and an increased level of HbA2 (α2δ2).
  • Thalassemias are inherited disorders caused by mutations in globin genes that decrease the synthesis of α- or β-globin. Decreased synthesis of one globin results not only in a deficiency of Hb, but also in red cell damage that is caused by precipitates formed from excess unpaired "normal" globin chains.
  • The diagnosis of β-thalassemia major can be strongly suspected on clinical grounds. Hb electrophoresis shows a profound reduction or absence of HbA and increased levels of HbF. The HbA2 level may be normal or increased. Similar but less severe changes are noted in patients affected by β-thalassemia intermedia.
  • Prenatal diagnosis of β-thalassemia is challenging, but can be made in specialised centres by DNA analysis.

Incorrect options:

  • ESR estimation, Spherocytes in blood smear, and bone marrow aspiration are not confirmatory or conclusive for Thalassemia major (Options A, B , C ruled out).

choices.text: Only i, ii, and iii are correct
Only i and iii are correct
Only ii and iv are correct

questions.text:
Which is/are the factors that affect the rate and degree of sickling in sickle cell disease?
i. I mean corpuscular haemoglobin concentration
ii. Haemoglobin S level
iii. Haemoglobin F level
iv. Mean corpuscular haemoglobin
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The following factors determine the rate at which the polymerisation of HbS and consequent sickling take place:

  1. Presence of non-HbS haemoglobin
  2. Intracellular concentration of HbS
  3. Total haemoglobin concentration
  4. Extent of deoxygenation
  5. Acidosis and dehydration
  6. Increased concentration of 2, 3 BPG in the red cells

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy came with abdominal distension and joint pain to the emergency. He had a history of jaundice as well. Identify the inclusion body present on the RBC in the given Giemsa stain peripheral smear.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Howell-Jolly bodies are remnants of RBC nuclei that are normally removed by the spleen. Thus, they are seen in patients who have undergone splenectomy or have functional asplenia (sickle cell anaemia).
  • Howell-Jolly bodies are one of many types of inclusions found in circulating erythrocytes.
  • They appear to look similar to Heinz bodies, which are present in patients with G6PD deficiency or other hemolytic anaemias. They are also confused with basophilic stippling, which is a process most attributed to lead toxicity, but can occur in other conditions such as thalassemia, sickle cell disease, vitamin B12/folate deficiency, and myelodysplastic syndrome.

Incorrect options:

Hb H (Option A) is an abnormal haemoglobin variant that forms due to a deficiency of alpha-globin chains in alpha-thalassemia. HbH is a tetramer of beta-globin chains (β4).

Pappenheimer bodies (Option B) are small, irregular, basophilic inclusions in red blood cells composed of ferritin aggregates, Non-heme iron, and Mitochondrial remnants. seen in conditions like sideroblastic anaemia, Hemolytic anaemias, Post-splenectomy, and Iron overload disorders.

Basophilic stippling (Option D) refers to the presence of small, blue-purple granular inclusions in RBCs when stained with Wright-Giemsa. These granules consist of Aggregated ribosomes and RNA remnants (due to impaired maturation or toxic damage to RBC precursors). Seen in Lead poisoning, Megaloblastic anaemia, Thalassemia, Myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS), Pyrimidine-5'-nucleotidase deficiency.

Substitution of lysine for glutamic acid at Beta-6 globin chain position
Substitution of valine for glutamic acid at Beta-6 globin chain position
Substitution of lysine for glutamic acid at Beta-26 globin chain position

questions.text: This is a peripheral smear of a 5-year-old boy referred from PHC with fever, jaundice and acute bone pain. Which genetic mutation causes this change?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This is a case of sickle cell anaemia, where there is substitution of valine for glutamic acid at the Beta-6 globin chain position.
  • The figure shows sickle cells, anisocytosis, poikilocytosis, and target cells.
  • From its onset, the disease runs an unremitting course punctuated by sudden crises. Homozygous sickle cell disease is usually asymptomatic until 6 months of age, when the shift from HbF to HbS is complete.
  • The anaemia is moderate to severe; most patients have hematocrits of 18% to 30% (normal range, 38%-48%). The chronic hemolysis is associated with hyperbilirubinemia and compensatory reticulocytosis.
  • In patients with sickle cell anaemia, HbA is completely replaced by HbS, whereas in heterozygous carriers, only about half is replaced. HbS differs from HbA by having a valine residue instead of a glutamate residue at the 6th amino acid position in β-globin.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male, originally from Greece, emigrated to the United States with his family when he was a child. He presents to an acute care clinic after falling from a chair and hitting his head, producing a laceration of the scalp. On physical examination, vitals are normal. A complete blood count reveals a white blood cell count of 7,100 cells/μL, RBC count of 5.2 million, haemoglobin of 11 g/dL, and Hct of 34%. The MCV is 50 fL. Of the following, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In this case, the Mentzer index is 9.6, suggestive of β-thalassemia minor
  • The patient has a microcytic anaemia; however, the MCV is very low, out of proportion to the high RBC.
  • MENTZER INDEX = MCV/RBC. If less than 13, it is suggestive of β-thalassemia trait.

Incorrect options:

Hereditary spherocytosis (Option A): MCV is either normal or slightly decreased.

β-thalassemia minor (Option C): The decrease in MCV is disproportionate to the decrease in Hb.

Anaemia of chronic disease (Option D): Anaemia of Chronic disease is characterised by low HCT

questions.text: A medical technologist is examining a blood smear and notes many red blood cells that are decreased in size, are hyperchromatic, and lack a central pallor. The lab requisition form indicates a history of systemic lupus erythematosus. There is no family history of anaemia. The medical technologist performs a direct Coombs test, which is positive. Of the following, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The above-mentioned Peripheral Blood picture indicates the presence of Spherocytes, which are found in a variety of conditions, including hereditary spherocytosis and warm and cold autoimmune hemolytic anaemias, but typically are not found in G6PD deficiency (Option D ruled out).
  • Hereditary spherocytosis and microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia will have a negative direct Coombs test (Option B, C ruled out), whereas warm autoimmune hemolytic anaemia will have a positive direct Coombs test because of IgG present on the surface of the red blood cells.
  • In this entity, hemolysis results from the binding of high-affinity autoantibodies to red cells, which are then removed from the circulation by phagocytes in the spleen and elsewhere.
  • In addition to frank erythrophagocytosis, incomplete consumption ("nibbling") of antibody-coated red cells by macrophages removes membrane and transforms red cells into spherocytes, which are rapidly destroyed in the spleen, just as in hereditary spherocytosis.
  • Warm antibody immune hemolytic anaemia is caused by immunoglobulin G (IgG) or (rarely) IgA antibodies that are active at 37°C. More than 60% of cases are idiopathic (primary), whereas another 25% are secondary to an underlying immunologic disorder (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus) or are induced by drugs.
  • The clinical severity is variable, but most patients have chronic mild anaemia and moderate splenomegaly and require no treatment.

questions.text: A medical technologist is examining a blood smear and notes many spherocytes. She performs a monospecific direct Coombs test, which is negative. The laboratory requisition form indicates that the patient was seen in the clinic and was diagnosed with infectious mononucleosis. Of the following, what is the agent responsible for the change in the red blood cells?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The underlying cause of the anaemia is IgM antibody binding to red blood cells.
  • Spherocytes are found in a variety of conditions, including hereditary spherocytosis and warm and cold autoimmune hemolytic anaemias.
  • Individuals with infectious mononucleosis can develop a cold autoimmune hemolytic anaemia, which has a negative monospecific direct Coombs test.
  • Cold antibody immune hemolytic anaemia usually is caused by low-affinity IgM antibodies that bind to red cell membranes only at temperatures below 30°C, such as occur in distal parts of the body (e.g., ears, hands, and toes) in cold weather. Although bound IgM fixes complement, the latter steps of the complement cascade occur inefficiently at temperatures lower than 37°C. As a result, most cells with bound IgM pick up some C3b but are not lysed intravascularly.
  • When these cells travel to warmer areas, the weakly bound IgM antibody is released, but the coating of C3b remains. Because C3b is an opsonin, the cells are phagocytosed by macrophages, mainly in the spleen and liver; hence, in most cases, the hemolysis is mainly extravascular.
  • The binding of pentavalent IgM also crosslinks red cells and causes them to clump (agglutinate). Sludging of blood in capillaries because of agglutination often produces Raynaud's phenomenon in the extremities of affected individuals.
  • Cold agglutinins sometimes also appear transiently during recovery from pneumonia caused by Mycoplasma spp. and infectious mononucleosis, producing a mild anaemia of little clinical importance.
  • Chronic forms of cold agglutinin hemolytic anaemia occur in association with certain B-cell neoplasms or as an idiopathic condition.

choices.text: Measurement of folate and B12 concentration

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy presents to a clinic with Fatigue, Pale skin, and Yellowish eyes. Hb is 9 g/dl, MCV is 78, MCHC is 38 g/dl. The peripheral blood picture is as shown.

Which of the following is the confirmatory test for the diagnosis of this condition
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The above peripheral blood smear shows a case of Hereditary Spherocytosis, which is sensitive to the Osmotic fragility test.
  • This disorder stems from inherited (intrinsic) defects in the red cell membrane that lead to the formation of Spherocytes-nondeformable cells that are highly vulnerable to sequestration and destruction in the spleen.
  • Hereditary spherocytosis is usually transmitted as an Autosomal Dominant trait; a more severe, autosomal recessive form of the disease affects a small minority of patients. The characteristic features are anaemia, splenomegaly, and jaundice.
  • The anaemia is variable in severity, ranging from subclinical to profound; most commonly, it is moderate in degree. Because of their spherical shape, red cells in hereditary spherocytosis show increased osmotic fragility when placed in hypotonic salt solutions, a characteristic that can help establish the diagnosis.

Incorrect options:

Options A, B , C: These tests are not conclusive for Hereditary Spherocytosis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to his primary care physician complaining of blood in his urine, which he first noticed this morning. He complains of fatigue. Physical examination shows scleral icterus. His urine is rose colored. CBC shows a TLC of 3.8 x 109 cells/L, a Hb of 8.2 g/dL, and a platelet count of 92 x 109 cells/L/L. Urinalysis reveals 1 red cell/hpf. Serum aminotransferases are normal, and the patient has a total bilirubin of 5.8 mg/dL with a direct bilirubin of 0.3 mg/ dL. A direct coombs test is negative; however, flow cytometry demonstrates abnormally low expression of CD55 and CD59 on the patient's blood cells. Which of the following complications of this disease is this patient most likely to die from?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient suffers from Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria. His urine is red-colored; however, he has only one red cell per hpf on urinalysis, suggesting hemoglobinuria rather than hematuria. Of the causes of death listed, the most likely is hepatic vein thrombosis.
  • Other common sites of thrombosis include the inferior vena cava and cerebral veins. The other conditions listed are not common causes of death for patients with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (Option A, C , D ruled out).
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is a hemolytic anaemia that stems from acquired mutations in PIG-A, a gene required for the synthesis of phosphatidylinositol glycan (PIG), which serves as a membrane anchor for many proteins. Because PIG-A is X-linked, normal cells have only one active PIG-A gene, a mutation of which is sufficient to cause PIG-A deficiency.
  • The pathogenic mutations in PNH occur in an early hematopoietic progenitor that is capable of giving rise to red cells, leukocytes, and platelets. Progeny of the PIG-A mutated clone lack the ability to make "PIG-tailed" proteins, including several that limit the activity of complement.
  • As a result, red cells derived from PIGA-deficient precursors are inordinately sensitive to lysis by the complement C5b-C9 membrane attack complex.
  • Leukocytes share the same deficiency but are less sensitive to complement than are red cells, and so red cells take the brunt of the attack.
  • The nocturnal hemolysis that gives PNH its name occurs because complement fixation is enhanced by the decrease in blood pH that accompanies sleep (owing to CO2 retention).
  • The most feared complication of PNH is thrombosis, which often occurs within abdominal vessels such as the portal vein and the hepatic vein. The prothrombotic state is also somehow related to excessive complement activity, as Eculizimab, an antibody that binds C5 and inhibits the assembly of the C5b-C9 membrane attack complex, greatly lessens the incidence of thrombosis as well as the degree of intravascular hemolysis.

questions.text: A 33-year-old Caucasian male is seen in the emergency department for pain and redness of the right buttock. He has started on trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and doxycycline. He returns to his family physician four days later because of a yellowing of his eyes. His physical examination is unremarkable except for mild jaundice and scleral icterus. A CBC shows a TLC of 10.2 x 109 cells/L, a Hb of 7.2 g/dL, and a platelet count of 260 x 109 cells/L/L. Total bilirubin is 6.2 mg/dL, and direct bilirubin is 0.3 mg/dL. Amino transferases are normal. Serum haptoglobin is undetectable. A peripheral blood smear is likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The onset of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia and anaemia after exposure to sulfamethoxazole is highly suggestive of Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency..
  • Heinz bodies are characteristic of G6PD deficiency.
  • G6PD deficiency is associated with transient episodes of intravascular hemolysis caused by exposure to an environmental factor (usually infectious agents or drugs) that produces oxidant stress. Incriminated drugs include antimalarials (e.g., primaquine), sulfonamides, nitrofurantoin, phenacetin, aspirin (in large doses), and vitamin K derivatives.

Incorrect options:

Pencil cells (Option A) would be expected in iron deficiency anaemia.

Spherocytes (Option B) are seen in hereditary spherocytosis

Sickle cells (Option D) Given the man's ethnicity, G6PD deficiency is more likely than sickle cell disease.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male with no significant past medical history is referred to haematology for evaluation of anaemia discovered incidentally on routine blood work. A CBC shows a leukocyte count of 3600/ul, RBC =5 million/ul cells/L and Hb of 10.1 g/dL. MCV is 66 fL. His serum ferritin level is 460 ng/mL. A haemoglobin electrophoresis test shows elevated HbA2-4.5%. A peripheral blood smear is likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical history and findings suggest β-thalassemia minor, where Target cells are seen in the Peripheral smear.
  • Unlike β-thalassemia major, patients with β-thalassemia minor usually only have a mild hypochromic, microcytic anaemia that resembles iron deficiency.
  • A peripheral blood smear would be expected to show some target cells. The other options are associated with other diseases (Options A, B, C and ruled out).
  • Numerous target cells are present in this patient with haemoglobin E and beta thalassemia trait. Target cells, or codocytes, have an excess of cell membrane relative to cell volume. Target cells can be seen in liver disease, and microcytic target cells may be seen in thalassemia.

Incorrect options:

Pencil cells (Option A) would be expected in iron deficiency anaemia.

Spherocytes (Option B) are seen in hereditary spherocytosis

Sickle cells (Option D) Given the man's ethnicity, G6PD deficiency is more likely than sickle cell disease.

questions.text: A 4-year-old African American child is evaluated in a haematology clinic for anaemia. The child has received multiple blood transfusions starting at the age of 10 months, but has not been transfused in the past 2 years due to social difficulties. On examination, the child has abnormally prominent cheekbones and forehead, a depressed nasal bridge, and dental malocclusion. Heart sounds are normal, but the point of maximal impulse is laterally displaced. His lungs are clear. The spleen is markedly enlarged. Which of the following laboratory results would be expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient has classic facies of Thalassemia major. The disease is characterised by a microcytic (hence low MCV), hypochromic (hence low MCHC) anaemia with anisocytosis (hence elevated RDW) (Option A ,D ruled out).
  • Ongoing red cell destruction results in an increased reticulocyte count (Option B ruled out), although the reticulocyte count is lower than would be expected given the severity of anaemia due to ineffective erythropoiesis.
  • The ineffective erythropoiesis suppresses hepcidin, leading to excessive iron absorption. The combination of excessive absorption and repeated iron loading due to transfusions produces iron overload in these patients. The ferritin in this case would be expected to be increased.
  • In β-thalassemia major, peripheral blood smears show marked microcytosis, hypochromia, poikilocytosis (variation in cell shape), and anisocytosis (variation in cell size). Nucleated red cells (normoblasts) are also seen which reflect the underlying erythropoietic drive.

questions.text: A 37-year-old male presents to his family physician with complaints of fatigue. A complete blood count is as follows: haemoglobin 11.7 g/dL, hematocrit of 34%, and MCV of 87 fL. Additional laboratory tests reveal a total bilirubin of 1.9 mg/dL, LDH of 563 U/L, and haptoglobin of 13 mg/dL. The urine is positive for both haemoglobin and hemosiderin. Of the following, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given scenario points to a case of Intravascular hemolysis, for which Babesiosis is the most probable cause in this situation.

  • The patient has anaemia, as indicated by the low haemoglobin, which is normocytic, as indicated by the MCV. The elevated total bilirubin, elevated LDH, and decreased haptoglobin indicate hemolysis, and the presence of haemoglobin and hemosiderin in the urine indicates intravascular hemolysis.
  • Hereditary spherocytosis and warm autoimmune hemolytic anaemia cause extravascular hemolysis (Option B ,D ruled out). Iron deficiency anaemia would be a microcytic anaemia (Option A ruled out). B12 deficiency would produce megaloblastic anaemia. Babesiosis causes intravascular hemolysis.
  • Babesiosis is caused by microscopic parasites that are spread by certain ticks and can cause intravascular hemolysis.
  • Babesia parasites reproduce in red blood cells, where they can be seen as cross-shaped inclusions (four merozoites asexually budding, but attached together forming a structure looking like a "Maltese cross") and cause hemolytic anaemia.

'MALTESE CROSS' seen as inclusion bodies in RBC

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the OPD with complaints of fatigue, yellowish skin, scleral icterus, and dark brown urine. Hb is 8 g/dl, LDH is 1500 U/l, and Indirect bilirubin is 4.2mg/dl. Which of the following will not be a finding in the above-mentioned scenario?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In intravascular hemolysis, destruction of RBC leads to Hemoglobinemia.
  • Excess of haemoglobin may be excreted by kidney,s leading to Haemoglobinuria.
  • Some of the haemoglobin is reabsorbed by the kidney and is converted to hemosiderin, which is then excreted as hemosiderinuria (Option B ruled out).
  • Free haemoglobin in plasmais bound to haptoglobin, and this complex is rapidly cleared by the mononuclear phagocytic system - Decreased haptoglobin (Option C ruled out)
  • When haptoglobin is depleted, free haemoglobin is oxidised to methemoglobin - methemoglobinemia
  • Excess heme groups are catabolized to bilirubin within the mononuclear phagocytic system - Increased indirect bilirubin and jaundice (Option D ruled out).
  • LDH is stored in blood. During hemolysis, this enzyme is released in the blood - Increased serum LDH.

questions.text: Hereditary spherocytosis is due to ______________ deficiency.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hereditary spherocytosis is caused by inherited defects in the membrane skeleton, a network of proteins that stabilises the lipid bilayer of the red cell. The major membrane skeleton protein is spectrin, a long, flexible heterodimer that self-associates at one end and binds short actin filaments at its other end.
  • These contacts create a two-dimensional meshwork that is connected to the transmembrane proteins band 3 and glycophorin via the linker proteins ankyrin, band 4.2, and band 4.1. Mutations that cause hereditary spherocytosis most frequently involve ankyrin, band 3, or spectrin.
  • The common feature of the pathogenic mutations is that they weaken vertical interactions between the membrane skeleton and intrinsic red cell membrane proteins.
  • This defect destabilises the lipid bilayer of red cells, which shed membrane vesicles into the circulation as they age. Little cytoplasm is lost in the process, and as a resul,t the surface area-to-volume ratio decreases progressively with time until the cells become spherical.

Incorrect options:

Invertin/Invertase/Sucrase (Option B) is an enzyme that hydrolyses Sucrose.

Cytokeratins (Option C) are a group of proteins that form the intermediate filaments within the cytoskeleton of epithelial cells

questions.text: A 37-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with complaints of generalised weakness, fatigue, yellowish discolouration of skin and sclera and dark yellow urine. Hb is 7.8. Unconjugated bilirubin is 3.2 mg/dl. Which of these will be a finding in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The above-mentioned scenario is suggestive of Extravascular hemolysis, caused by defects that increase the destruction of red cells by phagocytes, particularly in the spleen. Because extreme alterations of shape are necessary for red cells to navigate the splenic sinusoids, any reduction in red cell deformability makes this passage difficult, and red cells that become "stuck" are recognised and phagocytosed by resident splenic macrophages.This leads to Hyperbilirubinemia and jaundice, stemming from the degradation of haemoglobin in macrophages
  • Varying degrees of splenomegaly due to "work hyperplasia" of phagocytes in the spleen
  • If long-standing,the formation of bilirubin-rich gallstones (pigment stones) and an increased risk of cholelithiasis.
  • Hemoglobinemia and Hemosiderinuria are seen due to intravascular hemolysis. (Option A, B ruled out)

questions.text: Crew cut appearance on the skull and Gamna-gandy bodies are seen in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Crew-cut appearance of skull:

  • Given the presence of the 'Crewcut' appearance on the skull and Gamna-gandy bodies, the most probable answer from the given options is Sickle cell disease.
  • The anatomic alterations in sickle cell anaemia stem from
    1. severe chronic hemolytic anaemia,
    2. increased breakdown of heme to bilirubin, and
    3. microvascular obstructions, which provoke tissue ischemia and infarction.
  • There is a compensatory hyperplasia of erythroid progenitors in the marrow. The cellular proliferation in the marrow often causes bone resorption and secondary new bone formation, resulting in prominent cheekbones and changes in the skull resembling a "crewcut" in radiographs.
  • Extramedullary hematopoiesis may appear in the liver and spleen. In childre,n there is moderate splenomegaly (splenic weight up to 500 g) due to red pulp congestion caused by entrapment of sickled red cells. However, chronic splenic erythrostasis produces hypoxic damage and infarcts, whic,h with tim,e reduce the spleen to a useless nubbin of fibrous tissue. This process, referred to as auto-splenectomy, is complete by adulthood.
  • Gamna-gandy bodies are small yellow-brown splenic/hepatic nodules composed of Fibrotic tissue, Hemosiderin and Calcium deposits seen in conditions with Chronic splenic congestion and Hemosiderosis. Causes include Portal hypertension, Chronic Hemolytic anaemia, Chronic malaria and Schistosomiasis.

Incorrect options:

Options A, B , C: G6PD Deficiency, Hodgkin's Lymphoma, Hereditary Spherocytosis do not present with these findings.
